plants.name: Prunus serrulata
plants.description: A small tree known for its stunning pink to white flowers that herald the arrival of spring. It is widely cultivated in temperate regions and celebrated in festivals like Japan's Hanami.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late March to April (varies by region, some early bloomers in March)
plants.funFact: Cherry blossoms have been an important cultural symbol in Japan for centuries, representing the ephemeral nature of life.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: An evergreen perennial known for its white flowers that often bloom in late winter to early spring. Despite its common name, it blooms around Christmas and into early March in some areas.
plants.location: Mountainous regions of Central and Southern Europe
plants.funFact: The Christmas rose can bloom through snow, adding early-season interest to gardens.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: A hardy evergreen shrub that produces clusters of fragrant flowers throughout the warmer months. In Mediterranean climates, it can begin blooming as early as March.
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, cultivated in subtropical and tropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Despite its beauty, all parts of the oleander plant are highly toxic if ingested.

plants.name: Acacia pycnantha
plants.description: Australia's national floral emblem, this tree produces bright yellow, fluffy flower clusters in late winter to early spring, signaling seasonal change in southern Australia.
plants.bloomingSeason: July to November in Australia (Southern Hemisphere late winter to spring, meaning it blooms from July-November; not March in Australia). However, Acacia species bloom variably worldwide.
plants.funFact: Golden Wattle flowers contain numerous stamens that give the blossoms their characteristic fluffy appearance.
